elements.text: thanks

text:
One final thing that might be worth taking into account (assuming you reside in UK) is that there is a quite a bit of anti-gambling sentiment within the country, media and parts of government. UK gambling commission are proposing some changes that will force gaming operators to do things that might result in reduced betting activity over the coming years. This may or may not become legislation, and nobody knows for sure what would happen if it does, but it is something that causes some people concern in regards to profit drying up (I am certainly concerned about it).

I only mention for completeness and also because your last post makes it sound like you are pretty fed up with your current job and I'd not want you to go blind into this buying up historlcal data, finding some nice edge only for it to evaporate due to decreasing betting volumes if the gambling lanscape changes this year. I am sure plenty will disagree with this perhaps overly negative mindset I have though. I just think its sometihng to be aware of if you intend to put some heavy effort into this.

elements.text: if you were starting from scratch would you consider Crypto instead of sports?

text: <@UPMUFSGCR> I wouldn't but that's mainly because I know nothing about finance / quant stuff and when I've tried reading about it I find the maths involved incredibly dry and boring. Also you have to pay tax on crypto profit in UK now which was not the case when I first purchased crypto. If the bottom falls out of UK betting industry I'd probably consider moving abroad (or finding a way to legitimately carry on doing things with overseas operators) or just packing in and trying to get a job again. I do hear a few here make good money on crypto though, so maybe a better option. But you never know how the government are going to tackle that in future either. Possibly more longevity in crypro though than sports betting with the way things appear to be going. Just opinions and gut feeling though.

Would I comment out the line that is printing it, or set the level of the messages so these (info ?) type are missed. Thanks

text: Why do you want to turn them off, its warning you of something very bad happening

elements.text: Why do you want to turn them off, its warning you of something very bad happening

text: Maybe you could tune the threshold value (parameterise it) rather than totally ignoring them? Leave them in for say >500ms.

Well Ive had these on and off intermittently Liam since I started using Flumine (either when running locally or on AWS).
Some days its fine, last 3 or 4 days have been fine for instance..
I usually have the terminal window visible so i can keep my eye on it when doing the day job alongside...ie of any error messages etc..
When the latency message comes through it just streams down the page and I can see other messages
I know its there for a reason but its working and making profits etc

I was just thinking...I have two strats running on separate instances (the code/logic for the strat is slightly different on each)
When I get the latency messages I get it on both instances (never on just one or the other), so that would suggest its not the strat code then ?
Could well be the clock timing in some way as you say...

root.text:
Hello :wave:  apologies I'm new to this and I'm sure you've probably seen my questions 100 times before, but I was just hoping for a little direction if possible:

1. I'm looking to parse the historic data files for American football data and preferably to analyse in a csv file.  For this I thought I might need to use betfairlightweight rather than flumine? As I'm not looking to do automatic trading atm I thought BFW was the right program for that?
2. If so, I was looking at the <https://github.com/betcode-org/betfair/blob/master/examples/examplestreaminghistorical.py|example historical stream>. Given the data file structure is in the format of `{month}/{day}/{marketID}/{...bz2}` I guess I need to traverse the folders and load in each file individually?
3. I've seen people talk about recording prices themselves though the <https://github.com/betcode-org/flumine/blob/master/examples/strategies/marketrecorder.py|MarketRecorder> rather than buying historic data after the fact. Do you generally put that on an EC2 or something running 24/7?
Apologies if these are all very basic!

elements.text: Hello
apologies I'm new to this and I'm sure you've probably seen my questions 100 times before, but I was just hoping for a little direction if possible:

I'm looking to parse the historic data files for American football data and preferably to analyse in a csv file.  For this I thought I might need to use betfairlightweight rather than flumine? As I'm not looking to do automatic trading atm I thought BFW was the right program for that?
If so, I was looking at the
example historical stream
. Given the data file structure is in the format of
{month}/{day}/{marketID}/{...bz2}
I guess I need to traverse the folders and load in each file individually?
I've seen people talk about recording prices themselves though the
MarketRecorder
rather than buying historic data after the fact. Do you generally put that on an EC2 or something running 24/7?
Apologies if these are all very basic!

text:
the pitchforks may get pointed at me for this but - just an opposing view on betfair basic data. because it gets a very bad rap in here and needs some friends

• it is definitely useless if you’re trying to do anything low-latency/inplay/high frequency/purely market data-driven
• if your work (like mine) does not fall into this category, its a totally fine place to start. i found it extremely useful when starting out
• a runner’s last traded price accurate to within 1 minute (available in basic data) is far from useless. could be the thing that makes your purely fundamentals model into something profitable

text:
I don't reside in the UK, I have an Australian Betfair account (although I live elsewhere now).  The risk of lower betting volumes is certainly not insignificant, therefore I think it is better to make this a part time venture.

Regarding to Crypto, I'm also researching the opportunities of trading, which requires a different lense of understanding the mechanics.  But more generally, I still put a proportion of my savings toward holding crypto, sort of acting as an insurance against the current fiat (i.e.debt driven) monetary system

elements.text:

Regarding to Crypto, I'm also researching the opportunities of trading, which requires a different lense of understanding the mechanics.  But more generally, I still put a proportion of my savings toward holding crypto, sort of acting as an insurance against the current fiat (i.e.debt driven) monetary system
